bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, July 2, 1890

div1.p: Lazear writes about the weather and his plans to travel once his examinations are finished.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, July 2, 1890
div1.p:
I received your letter of
June 19 on Tuesday Monday and also the
papers. I am sorry to hear that you
are having such hot weather.
I see by the papers (Edinburgh) that
they are having very hot weather in the
West now. I hope you have gone
to the mountains and are escaping
it. I am very much obliged to you
for ordering the “Post” for me. It has
not come yet but I suppose it will
by the next mail which reaches me
tomorrow.

I have nothing at all to tell about
my doings here except that I have
been very busy and have had time
to see nothing. It has rained
off and on principally on. I never
saw such a place for rain.

It was clear for a short time
on Sunday afternoon and I seized
the opportunity to go to Arthur's Seat. I
went up by a new way which is
shorter but more steep than the
other. The view from the top is certainly
magnificent, especially on the side
away from Edinburgh, on that side
the smoke of the town obscures
everything.

I was sorry to hear that Judge Ewing
had not decided the case. It is remarkable
how slow the law is. I can't see that
there is any excuse for it. Why
should lawyers be allowed to get
from one to fifty years behind in their
work. The rest of us are expected
to be prompt and why shouldn't the
same be required of them.

After next Tuesday I shall not be
so busy as I am at present
as on that day the last of Sir
William Turner's examinations takes
place. After that time I hope to
get to see some of the places
around Edinburgh that I have
not yet visited. I want to see
Roslin, Craigmiller Castle and the
Forth Bridge. I also want to take
a trip to the lakes. I can make
the trip of Loch Katrine, Loch Lomond
and the Trosachs all in one
day getting back to Edinburgh
in the evening. I shall go
down to London on the 17th or 18th
of July.

I hope you have gone to Bedford or
some place in the mountains for the
hot spell. You certainly ought to
do it. It would build you up
wonderfully. You must be sure and
not let people bother you.
div1.closer:
Your affectionate son J. W. L. I find that I did not send you an
ivy leaf that I got at the ruins
of Lennox Castle. I send it now.
